pros: LiNK's heart is 100% in the right place. If you are looking for dedicated teammates, look no further. Focus on the North Korean people and honest and earnest engagement with the public is in their DNA. Also, using technology efficiently to have a broad impact is inspiring and what so many other small nonprofits need.
cons:
Organizational maturity is unfortunately still lacking even after many attempts to improve. I think it has nothing to do with care and everything to do with foresight and context.

LiNK started out scrappy but unfortunately in many ways it has stayed that way. It is very common to hear "this is the ways we do it" when employees are being overworked without extra pay or encouraged to give a bit more. I understand at times this is necessary but unfortunately it doesn't have to always be this way.

After my time at LiNK I've gone on to work for several organizations who challenged this idea and were good examples of not expecting too much of their staff. You really can have that passion and heart and get paid well and love your impact in the world. You can have it all!

pros: Really making a difference here
cons: Expensive area to work as an intern

pros: everything is amazing i love it
cons: there are no cons to this company

pros:
- Lasting friendships 
- Opportunities are there if you are self motivated
- Inspires young people to always choose empathy and compassion 
- Positive work culture outside of upper management
cons:
If you’re looking for your first internship, this is the place for you! If you’re looking for a well rounded career, this is not the place for you!

- Distant and blissfully ignorant Vice President. 
- Disorganized and lack of accountability. I went to urgent care due to LiNK's inattentiveness, and had to pay.
- Heavily relies on interns as their main source of labor. Interns expected to work overtime with no compensation. Constant turnover of interns and burnt out staff. All leads to an unsustainable structure. 
- No career path. No strategy to draw new talent and retain existing talent.
- No pay. No stipend. 
- Constantly guilted and pressured to run errands (both during and outside of working hours) that were irrelevant, unethical, and counterproductive to internship goals because of the cause. Priorities vary among interns- I did not take out student loans to be fetching and driving people from the airport. It's called Uber. A service that you pay for.

pros: Really view internship as a program that is meant to develop skills and not just help with small tasks. A lot of the work you do is just as important as full-time staff members. First few days of internship are very carefully planned to train all interns on LiNK history and the North Korean issue. Throughout internship they try to plan fun activities with interns.
cons:
Still a growing organization so not all processes are fully in place. However, for their size they are still pretty well organized.

Living conditions are currently not optimal. It is nice that housing is provided, but the current house has 7 rooms and 4 bathrooms for 15-30 people. This is something they are working on though.

pros: Amazing internship were you are valued as part of the staff. You get as much out of it as you put into it. Your manager also acts as a personal and professional mentor. They want to help you grow professionally and will have weekly check-ins with you to make sure you are meeting your work, personal, and career goals. Tons of networking opportunities. The office environment is fun and passionate. Everyone works hard because each person clearly understands how important their work is to the organization, interns included. Great work-life balance. The office encourages you to explore the city and try new things outside of work.  Honestly, if you want to learn about the North Korean issue, have an tangible impact making a difference at a nonprofit,  and hone your professional skills this is the internship for you.
cons: Knowing that there may not be a hiring opportunity at the end of your internship with the company.

pros:
Awesome work culture, engaging staff, a friendly environment.
Provided housing and transportation
Lots of bonding events and excursions 
Educational and very thorough with up-to-date knowledge with a lot of resources around the world
cons:
One full-time employee was known to be under a lot of pressure and prone to outbursts and treating other co-workers rudely - not sure if he's still there though
Unpaid internship (but there were benefits)

pros: As a GE engagement intern, I was able to connect with Rescue Team leaders from all around the world to set goals and develop their teams to reach those goals. It never felt like typical intern "busy work", but work that was actually really important to the organization and their strategy. I felt like I had a lot of opportunities to learn from the staff and ask for career advice. I had a great relationship with my supervisor where I could easily ask her for help with my work, and when I asked her if I could sit in on staff meetings she happily obliged. I learned a lot about the situation in North Korea and the interns were given opportunities to learn in other settings, like attending panel discussions and exhibits on refugees. I really enjoyed my internship!
cons: I had a lot of work and became overwhelmed at times. However, my supervisor took that into consideration and hired more interns for the next term

review_title: Management needs to clean its act up
pros: Good vacation policy, good work culture outside of management, you make friends there, work parties
cons: Non-competitive pay, management, frequent threatening of budget issues (layoffs, nonpayment, etc), often management is working on outside projects during company time

review_title: Some of the best 4 months of my life
pros:
- Very worthwhile work - very rarely did mundane work, and even on the rare occasions that I had to do some less exciting tasks, I knew why I was doing it and why it mattered, which kept me well motivated.
- Great work-life balance.
- Continuing to grow, and it’s an exciting time to join the team.
- Great collegiate atmosphere, and a young, vibrant team - former colleagues now close personal friends that I still meet up with regularly.
- Felt very invested in as a colleague and individual - their motto is ‘people over politics’ and this human-focused approach applies internally to the staffers/interns/volunteers just as it does with their external partners.
- Respects the resettled North Koreans and interacts with them as equals, as people with potential, not as those who are ‘less fortunate’ and so they have to ‘help’.
- Amazing office facilities in Seoul
cons: - Internship too short! Wish I could have stayed for longer.

review_title: Best job I've had so far
job_title: Human Resources & Recruitment in Torrance, CA
pros: This place has the most passionate, and driven people I've ever worked with. Working with them really made me realize what it means to be fulfilled by your job, rather than it being something just to make ends meet. I was allowed to work on several amazing projects, adding to my pool of experiences and got great, honest feedback. It was an incredible 4 months.
cons: Working at a small Non-profit, you have to be willing to take on multiple roles. Also, if you prefer a highly structured hierarchical work environment, the culture here may throw you off.

pros: I got to work with the most passionate, driven individuals that valued humanity every day. You were given the creative freedom to really grow your position and your department. Management always did a good job of supporting me if I did not know how to navigate certain parts of my job in the first few months. The organization embraces taking risks and understands that no great good can come out of doing the same things over and over again. I went into work every day, thrilled to be working, and I honestly have never felt that way about a 9 to 5 before.
cons: None that I can think of - I loved working here!

pros:
Interning at LiNK is more than just an internship that will stand out on your resume. It is a whole experience. 
The best part of working for LiNK is that everyday, you get to be a part of a movement that changes the world, in such a fun and cool way. 
I got to learn how to better engage with people, communicate with them in a more convincing way, and I was able to meet amazing people that I would have never been able to meet if it wasn't for this internship. 
Your life will never be the same after working for LiNK.
cons: LiNK spoils you so that you can't work for any other company anymore.

pros: You will meet some of the most awesome people from all over the world. There's free housing and you'll be close to LA. The staff are also really great people as well. And you'll learn more about North Korea here than anywhere else.
cons: Unpaid internship unless you're a nomad where you'll receive a small stipend.

pros: My experience at LiNK is something that I'll be taking wherever I go.  Through the work that you do and the people you meet, you can't help but become super passionate about LiNK and the North Korean people. If you're on the fence about interning at LiNK, I would say JUST DO IT. You won't regret it!
cons: After interning at LiNK, it's hard to imagine myself working in a more traditional office setting.

pros:
People are young, bright, kind, and passionate. 
Many of the benefits (flexible work hours, working off-site, unlimited day off, etc) for staff are also applicable to interns. 
Many great training opportunities. 
Interns get to be part of real projects that have important, lasting impact to the mission.
cons: It is an NGO, so don't expect the monetary compensation to match that of for profit organizations.

pros: Open space concept; family oriented; celebration of every rescue missions; family/pet-friendly workspace; free breakfast from time to time
cons: salary is too low; interns are unpaid and yet overworked (minimally 40h/week)

pros: Healthy, awesome work culture. My supervisor was like a mentor to me, gave honest and constructive feedbacks, respected my views, and taught me a lot. Feel valued working there and the people are a joy to be around. The office dogs are adorable.
cons: Could do with a little more structure, and paid internships.

pros: They take good care of the interns and make sure everyone gets involved. You will learn a lot while helping them bring about change. It's a good internship if you want to figure out whether nonprofit is right for you. Great open work environment.
cons: Unpaid but worth it for the experience.

pros: The atmosphere is nice, even as an intern you feel like you're doing something important, open/laid-back environment, meet a lot of cool people
cons: If you're an intern, the intern house can get pretty packed/dirty depending on how many are in your intern class - but its free!

pros:
Was wonderful knowing the work you were doing was for a great cause
Small team and everyone is very nice
Free housing
cons: Its not paid but you get free housing and transportation so you just have to worry about food and personal care. Not too big of a con

pros: Great work culture. The non-profit cause they work for truly makes a difference in the world
cons: None that I can currently think of

pros: Loved working here, thought that the environment was very supportive and loved being able to work with amazing and passionate people
cons: Sometimes felt like I could've been more useful and given more responsibilities

pros:
Open work environment
Interns valued like full time staff
Working for a great cause!
Free housing and transport while interning :D
cons: House is kinda far from things to do outside of work

pros:
- Great vibe!
- Supervisors care a lot about what interns learn
- Office dogs
- Free house, vans
- Flexible work hours
cons:
- Still young organization, so supervisors don't have that much experience.
- Unpaid

pros: highly motivated staff, working closely with the Director and CEO, entrepreneurial and vibrant work atmosphere
cons: sometimes had to work overtime, unpaid

job_title: Marketing and Communications Intern in Long Beach, CA
pros: You have the opportunity to work with passionate people on an incredibly meaningful movement.
cons: There aren't any  cons I can think of.

pros: Great people to work with.
cons: Could be a pro: still a growing (small org), so things are not as stable and set.

pros: Great cause, inspirational people, and fun growing environment
cons: Not enough available positions to move up and may work lots of overtime

pros: direct responsibility and chance to learn from day one
cons: lack of employee development and support

pros: free food, free housing, great coworkers
cons: not allowed any contact with the outside world

pros: work culture and amnesties in the company
cons: work load and peer pressure from the company

pros: Great people, great culture.
cons: Day-day operations can get mundane.
